A newly discovered BiF3 photocatalyst with a high positive valence band Chenkai Feng a Fei Teng a ⁎ Zailun Liu a Chao Chang a Yunxuan Zhao a Shurong Wang a Mindong Chen a Wenqing Yao b Yongfa Zhu b a Jiangsu Engineering and Technology Research Center of Environmental Cleaning Materials (ECM), Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment Monitoring and Pollution Control (AEMPC), Jiangsu Joint Laboratory of Atmospheric Pollution Control (APC), Collaborative Innovation Center of Atmospheric Environment and Equipment Technology (AEET), School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Nanjing University of Information Science & Technology, China Jiangsu Engineering and Technology Research Center of Environmental Cleaning Materials (ECM) Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment Monitoring and Pollution Control (AEMPC) Jiangsu Joint Laboratory of Atmospheric Pollution Control (APC) Collaborative Innovation Center of Atmospheric Environment and Equipment Technology (AEET) School of Environmental Science and Engineering Nanjing University of Information Science & Technology China b Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, China Department of Chemistry Tsinghua University China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 25 5873 1090; fax: +86 25 5873 1090. Graphical abstract BiF3 with a high positive valence band is discovered as a new, efficient photocatalyst. Herein, we, for the first time, introduce BiF3 as a new photo catalyst. The ab initio density functional theory (DFT) calculation has been carried out to insight the electronic structures of BiF3. It is amazing that BiF3 has a highly positive valence band and a wide direct band gap of 3.94eV. It is further found that the high-electronegativity fluorine (χ =10.41eV) significantly contributes to a highly positive valence band. Under UV-light irradiation (λ <420 nm), the photo activity of BiF3 is 2.1 times higher than that of commercial rutile TiO2 for the degradation of rhodamine B (RhB). It is expected that the photo catalysts would be greatly enriched by the discovery of BiF3 as a new, efficient photo catalyst. Keywords BiF3 Positive valence band Fluorine Photocatalyst 1 Introduction Due to the increasingly worsening environmental pollution and energy shortage, it is highly needed to develop the new environmental remediation and clean energy technologies. Semiconductor photo catalysis is a promising way to deal with the environmental pollution and solar energy conversion. Since the first report by Fujishima and Honda [1], photo catalytic degradation of organic pollutants has been intensively studied. Under light irradiation, the electrons in valence band (VB) can be excited to the conduction band (CB). The band–band excitation produces the reductive electrons and oxidative holes. Furthermore, the holes and thus, the produced OH radicals are the powerful oxidative species, can effectively degrade organic pollutants [2,3]. Nevertheless, the photo catalytic activities of the presently existing photo catalysts are not high enough to meet the practical requirements. Thus, it is highly desirable to find the new, efficient photo catalysts. The bismuth-containing compounds are reported to have the high photo catalytic activities for the degradations of dyes and have been widely researched [4–6]. For instance, Su and Wang [4] have reported that BiOF exhibited a higher activity than commercial Degussa P25 TiO2 for the degradation of rhodamine B (RhB). Pan and Zhu [5] have reported that BiPO4 showed a higher photo catalytic activity than commercial Degussa P25 TiO2, for the degradation of methyl orange (MO). Yang et al. [6] have reported that [Bi6O6(OH)3](NO3)3·1.5H2O exhibited a comparable photo catalytic activity to that of commercial Degussa P25 TiO2 for the degradation of phenol. These results suggest that bismuth-based compounds could be the promising efficient photo catalysts for the degradation of organic dyes. On base of the advantages of bismuth-based compounds, we have tried to explore the other bismuth-containing compound (i.e., BiF3). In the past years, BiF3 has been mainly used as the composite material of glasses [7] and lithium-ion battery electrodes [8]. To the best of our knowledge, there is no report on BiF3 as a photo catalyst. Herein, we found that BiF3 had a greatly higher photo catalytic activity than commercial rutile TiO2 for the degradation of RhB dye. Compared with TiO2, it has a highly positive VB, which favors to generate the high oxidizing ability holes, maybe also leading to the formation of hydroxyls. Moreover, the photo catalytic activity of BiF3 is found to be mainly predominated by fluorine, which differs from the other bismuth-containing compounds. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on using BiF3 as a photo catalyst, which has not unknown before. As a result, the photo catalysts could be greatly diversified by the discovery of BiF3 as a new photo catalyst. This could provide us that fluorine-containing compounds could be developed as the new, efficient photocatalysts. In this study, BiF3 is synthesized by a simple water-bath method, and the Ab initio density functional theory (DFT) calculation has been used to insight the electronic structures of BiF3. Further, RhB dye is chosen as the probe molecule to evaluate the photo catalytic activity of BiF3. 2 Experimental All reagents are of analytical grade, purchased from Beijing Chemical Reagents Company of China, and used without further purification. 2.1 Synthesis of BiF3 The sample was synthesized by a simple water bath deposition method. Typically, 1mmol Bi(NO3)3·5H2O was dissolved in 40mL deionized water. Then, 3mmol NH4F was added to the above solution under stirring. Subsequently, the pH value of mixture was adjusted to 3–4 by an ammonium hydroxide solution (0.01molL−1), and the mixture heated in water bath at 80°C for 3h under stirring. Finally, the sample was centrifuged, washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol for three times, respectively. The sample was dried in air at 60°C for 12h. 2.2 Characterization The crystal phases of the samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku D/max-2550VB), using graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.154nm) in the range of 20–80° (2θ) at a scanning rate of 5°min−1. The accelerating voltage and applied current were 40kV and 50mA. The morphology and size of the products was characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi SU-1510) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2100F) with selected area electron diffraction (SAED). UV–vis diffused reflectance spectra (DRS) were obtained using a UV–vis spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, UV-2550) using BaSO4 as the background. Nitrogen sorption isotherms were performed at 77K and <10−4 bar on a Micromeritics ASAP2010 gas adsorption analyzer. The sample was degassed at 150°C for 5h before measurements. Surface area was calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. 2.3 EIS measurement Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed from 0.1HZ to 100kHz at an open circuit potential of 0.3V, and an alternating current (AC) voltage amplitude of 5mV. The data were analyzed by ZSimWin software. 2.4 Theoretical calculations The simulations of band structures, total and partial densities of states (DOS) were calculated by density functional theory (DFT) as implemented in the CASTEP. The calculations were carried out using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) level, and Perdew–Burke–Ernzerh (PBE) formalism for combination of exchange and correlation function. The cut-off energy is chosen as 380eV, and a density of (3×2×5) Monkhorst-Pack K-point was adopted to sample the Brillouin zone. 2.5 Evaluation of photo catalytic activity Under UV light irradiation, the photo catalytic activities of the samples were evaluated using RhB as the probing molecule. Typically, 0.1g of BiF3 was added into the dye solution (200mL, 10mgL−1), which was irradiated with a 500W Xe arc lamp equipped with ultraviolet light (λ ≤420nm). Under darkness, the suspension was stirred for 60min to reach an adsorption–desorption equilibrium of dye molecules on the photo catalyst. During photoreaction, 4mL of suspension was collected at a given interval time and centrifuged to remove the particles. The concentration of dye was determined by using UV–vis spectrophotometer. 3 Results 3.1 Formation of BiF3 The samples are prepared by a simple water-bath method, in which the effects of Bi/F molar ratio on the samples have been mainly investigated while keeping the other reaction parameters constant (Fig. 1 ). At low Bi/F molar ratios, the as-prepared samples (Samples 1 and 2) are mainly composed of BiF3 phase, along with the small amounts of monoclinic BiOF (JCPDS73-1595), pentacle Bi2O3 (JCPDS 71-0467) and the unknown impurity phases. Comparing Samples 1 with 2, the diffraction peaks of BiF3 are weaker, but the impurities peaks are more intense. At Bi/F=1/3 (molar ratio), all the diffraction peaks are in good agreement with standard card (JCPDS: 51-0944). No impurities peaks, such as Bi2O3, BiOF and Bi, can be detected, indicating the formation of phase-pure BiF3. Furthermore, we have investigated the influence of the pH value on the samples in Fig. 2 . With increasing the pH value, the diffraction peaks of BiF3 become weaker, and BiF3 can not form at the high alkaline concentrations. Typically, Fig. 3 (a) reveals that the formed BiF3 nanoparticles are about 30nm in sizes, and its size uniform can be observed from Fig. S1 (Electronic Supporting Information). From Fig. 3(b), the lattice fringe spacings are determined to be 0.207nm and 0.338nm, which can be well indexed to the (110) and (111) planes of BiF3, respectively. The polycrystalline nature of BiF3 can be revealed by the selected area electron diffraction pattern (SAED) (Fig. 3c). 3.2 Degradation activity We have performed the degradation experiment without adding BiF3 photocatalyst (Fig. S2, ESI). Without adding BiF3, there was a small degradation of RhB under UV irradiation (about 25%/50min); after adding BiF3, 78.5% RhB was degraded. The results validate the degradation performance of BiF3. Fig. 4 (a) shows the degradation activity of rhodamine B (RhB) by BiF3 and commercial rutile TiO2. BiF3 obviously exhibits a higher photo catalytic activity than commercial rutile TiO2. The apparent reaction rate constant (k a) of BiF3 is 5.3min−1, 1.3 times higher than that of rutile TiO2 (Fig. 4(b)). Furthermore, Fig. 5 (a) shows the cycle stability of BiF3 for the photodegradation of RhB. After four cycles, the degradation activity of BiF3 does not decrease. Furthermore, Fig. 5(b) shows the XRD patterns of the sample after four cycles. No obvious change can be observed for the XRD pattern, demonstrating a high stability of BiF3. 3.3 Oxidation species The holes and radicals trapping experiments have been performed to explore the photo catalytic degradation process by BiF3, in which EDTA (Ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid) and DMSO (Dimethyl sulfoxide) are used as the hole and radical scavengers, respectively [9,10]. As observed from Fig. 6 , the photo catalytic activity of BiF3 decreases slightly after adding EDTA; In contrast, the degradation reaction has been almost completely inhibited after adding DMSO. It is obvious that hydroxyl radicals are the major active species to oxidize RhB dye. 3.4 Photoelectrochemical properties Fig. 7 shows the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) which is measured to investigate the electron transfer ability of BiF3. Obviously, the semicircle radius of BiF3 electrode in a high-frequency region is larger than the commercial rutile TiO2. A smaller semicircle radius in a Nyquist plot means a smaller electric resistance of electrode [11], which means BiF3 has a higher electric resistance than commercial rutile TiO2. This indicates that the higher activity of does not resource from the charge separation efficiency, but from the other factor. Furthermore, Fig. 8 (a) shows the Tauc plot of BiF3 (the inset of UV–vis diffusion reflectance spectra (UV-DRS)). In the absorption edge region of semiconductor, the square of absorption coefficient is linear with direct optical transition energy, whereas the square root of absorption coefficient linear with indirect optical transition energy [33]. As observed from Fig. 8(b), the plots of absorbency2 ((αhν)2) and absorbency1/2 ((αhν)1/2) vs. photon energy (hν) in the absorption edge region are different: the plot of (αhν)2 vs. hν is nearly linear, while the plot of (αhν)1/2 vs. hν deviates from the fitted straight line. Hence, we could hold that the absorption edge of BiF3 is caused by direct optical transition. The optical band gap of BiF3 can be determined by Eq. (1) as follows, in which n is dependent on the optical transition type of a semiconductor (n =1, direct absorption; n =4, indirect absorption) [34]. (1) α h v = A ( h v − E g ) n / 2 where α, ν, A and E g represent absorption coefficient, photon frequency, proportionality constant and band gap, respectively. The UV-DRS spectrum shows that the absorption edge of BiF3 occurs at 345nm and the band gap is determined to be 3.94eV [12]. BiF3 has a wider band gap than that (3.23eV) of anatase TiO2. 3.5 Theory calculation The ab initio density functional theory (DFT) calculations have been carried out to insight the electronic structures of BiF3. Fig. 9 (a) shows that BiF3 has a direct band gap and its band gap is calculated to be 3.70eV, which is a slightly narrower than the UV-DRS result (3.94eV). This difference is a common feature of DFT calculations [13]. Accordingly, a reasonable dispersed energy can be observed obviously, which would favor the transportation of the photogenerated electrons and holes, thus improving the photocatalytic activity [32]. Fig. 9(b) shows the total density of states (TDOS) and the partial density of states (PDOS) on Bi, F and BiF3. Its top of valence band (VB) is composed of both F 2p and a portion of Bi (6s, 6p) orbitals. The Bi 6s and F 2p levels can form a preferable hybridized valence band, increasing the separation efficiency of electrons and holes [14,15]. In addition, the Bi 6p orbital and a small part of F 2p orbital constitute the bottom of conduction band (CB). This suggests that upon photo excitation, the electron transfer can occur from the hybrid orbit of both F 2p and Bi 6s to the empty Bi 6p orbit. 4 Discussion The BET area of BiF3 is determined to be 17.6m2 g−1, which is only one third of that (50m2 g−1) commercial Rutile TiO2. So it is reasonable to believe that there are the other crucial factors to predominate the high activity of BiF3. First, we have calculated its conduction and valence band positions (E CB, E VB) using Eqs. (1) and (2) as follows [16]: (2) E V B = χ − E e + 0.5 E g (3) E C B = E V B − E g where χ, E e and E g are the geometric mean of Mulliken’s electronegativities, the energy of free electrons on the hydrogen scale (∼4.5eV) and the band gap, respectively. The calculation result shows that the Mulliken’s electronegativity (8.53eV) of BiF3 is mainly predominated by the high electronegativity (χ =10.41eV) of F−. The E VB value is calculated to be 6.00eV (vs. N.H.E), which is two times higher than that (2.9eV) of anatase TiO2 [17] and is also higher than those of the other existing photo catalysts (Table 1 ). The highly positive VB position is expect to endow the photo generated holes with a high oxidizing ability. As a result, the photo generated holes are more easy to react with H2O or OH− to produce active OH radicals [2]. Hence, we hold that it is the highly positive VB position that leads to a high photo activity of BiF3. It should noted that due to a positive conduction band, the excited electrons can not react with oxygen to form O2 −, as shown in Figs. S3 and 4 (ESI). Second, Fig. 9(c) presents the super crystal cell of BiF3. Obviously, the fluorines expose on the surface of BiF3. The electronegativity of fluorine is much higher than that of hydroxyl group (OH) [18,19], thus, the fluorine exposed can strongly adsorb or trap electrons, namely, fluorine can effectively affect the electron distribution in BiF3. This phenomenon has been defined as an electron inductive effect [5]. As a result, the photo generated holes could react with H2O or OH− to form more hydroxyl radicals (OH), or directly oxidize organic chemicals. It has been widely reported that fluorine can effectively improve photo catalytic activity of photo catalysts [20–22]. For example, the photo catalytic activity of TiO2 has been significantly enhanced by the surface modification and/or the doping of fluorine [23–28]. What is more, the improved photo catalytic activities are also observed over the other fluorinated photo catalysts, such as SrTiO3 [29], ZnWO4 [30], BiWO3 and Bi2O3 [31], and so on. In a word, an improved separation efficiency of charges can be expected due to the electronegativity of fluorine. It should be pointed out that BiF3 can only show photocatalytic activity under ultraviolet light irradiation that is not match well with the current tendency toward a solar light-driven photocatalyst. Therefore, the future study will focus on further solving this problem by the doping of cation ion or coupling with the other semiconductors. 5 Conclusions To conclude, BiF3 has a highly positive VB that favors to form more hydroxyl radicals. A high separation efficiency of charges mainly results from an electronic induction effect by the high-electronegativity fluorine. As a result, BiF3 has a high photo catalytic activity under UV irradiation for the degradation of RhB. The discovery of BiF3 as a new photo catalyst could greatly contribute to the enrichment of photo catalyst diversity. Moreover, this could provide us that fluorine-containing compounds could be developed as the new, efficient photocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: Herein, we, for the first time, introduce BiF3 as a new photo catalyst. The ab initio density functional theory (DFT) calculation has been carried out to insight the electronic structures of BiF3. It is amazing that BiF3 has a highly positive valence band and a wide direct band gap of 3.94eV. It is further found that the high-electronegativity fluorine (χ =10.41eV) significantly contributes to a highly positive valence band. Under UV-light irradiation (λ <420 nm), the photo activity of BiF3 is 2.1 times higher than that of commercial rutile TiO2 for the degradation of rhodamine B (RhB). It is expected that the photo catalysts would be greatly enriched by the discovery of BiF3 as a new, efficient photo catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: A newly discovered BiF3 photocatalyst with a high positive valence band
